title: Dad sues Tesla after teens died in fiery crash while driving at 116mph
text:
Parents of Edgar Monseratt Martinez (top right) and Barrett Riley (Bottom right) have sued Tesla, blaming the electric car company for their sons’ deaths. (Picture: NBC/NTSB)

A father is suing Tesla after his son and another teen burned to death in a fiery crash while driving at 116mph.

In the lawsuit, parents Edgar Monserratt and Esperanza Martinez de Monserratt acknowledged that their 18-year-old son Edgar’s friend, Barret Riley, 18, was driving at an incredibly high rate of speed before the crash that killed them both on May 8, 2018 in For Lauderdale, Florida.

However, Edgar’s parents claim that the 2014 Tesla Model S should have never gone that fast, the Miami Herald reports.

Three days before the deadly crash, Barrett got a ticket for driving at 112mph through a 50mph zone, according to the suit.

The next day, Barrett’s parents brought the car to Tesla to install a device that limited the car’s speed to 85mph, the lawsuit claims.

According to the lawsuit, the Tesla mechanics ‘improperly removed the speed limiter/governor without the permission and consent of’ Riley’s parents.

Barret’s father, James Riley has also filed a similar lawsuit.

'Teen mother sliced newborn baby's neck then hid the body in her purse'

Both parents blame the electric car’s lithium-ion battery for exploding and causing a deadly inferno when the Tesla hit a concrete wall.

The Fort Lauderdale Fire Department did not see a visible fire when they responded to the crash, but they sprayed it with water and foam anyway, according to a National Transportation Safety Board investigation.

‘During the loading of the car for removal from the scene, the battery reignited and was quickly extinguished. Upon arrival at the storage yard, the battery reignited again. A local fire department responded to the storage yard and extinguished the fire,’ the NTSB report says.

Although one of the lawsuits claims the crash should have been ‘entirely survivable,’ Tesla released a statement earlier this year saying: ‘No car could have withstood high-speed crash of this kind.’
description: Parents are suing Tesla after two teens died in a fiery car crash in Fort Lauderdale, Florida.
